title: Close Call / Namjoon x Reader
body:
Your first encounter with sasaengs could have ruined your relationship if Namjoon and his friends hadn’t reacted fast enough.

pairing: Namjoon x Reader (feat. Hoseok)

warnings: angst

words: 2.6k

ANON REQUEST: Namjoon wanting to break up with you over the phone and you realize it’s not him.

“I don’t want to hang up,” Namjoon sighed on the other end of the call. You couldn’t hear him very clearly because the connection in the cabin he was staying in was just awful, but you still couldn’t bring yourself to end the phone call.

“Me neither,” you admitted. “I’ll miss talking to you in those few upcoming days.”

“I know,” he said. Namjoon and his groupmates were going to climb the Alps for the next few days and they wouldn’t have connection, so this was your last phone call with your boyfriend until he got back to the cabin in three days. “You’ll be okay, though, right?”

“Of course,” you said, your heart warming up. “You stay safe as well, okay? Don’t lose anything, especially not any limbs.”

He laughed at this. “I will try not to. We’ll be taking a safe track and, besides, the filming crew will be with us.”

“You’re basically remaking the movie Everest, aren’t you?” you sighed, still concerned about your boyfriend – as clumsy as he was – going out to climb the mountains for the few upcoming days with no way for you to check if he was okay.

“Not really, we won’t be going up very high and I don’t think the Alps are quite as dangerous,” Namjoon said. “Although, I’ve never seen the movie, so you know – maybe this will turn out to be Everest: Bangtan Edition.”

You were the one laughing now.

“Please don’t actually attempt to climb the Everest on your next trip,” you asked half-jokingly.

“As long as you don’t mention this idea to Jungkook, I think we’re fine,” Namjoon replied, both of you smiling in your respectful bedrooms, hundreds and hundreds of kilometers between you.

“Stay safe, please,” you asked again after a moment’s silence. “And give my best wishes to the rest of the team.”

“Will do,” your boyfriend said, sighing deeply as he realized – after noticing that it was well after 1am in his timezone already – that he couldn’t prolong his conversation with you any longer. “I have to go, baby.”

“I know,” you said, trying not to sound too sad because you were really happy for him – he was going to experience something amazing with his friends – but, at the same time, you have never gone more than one day without talking to him in any way, so this was stressful. “Get some rest tonight.”

“Okay,” he replied. “I love you.”

“I love you, too.”

“I’ll call you in three days,” he promised then. “Take care of yourself for me, baby.”

The days when you didn’t talk to your boyfriend didn’t really drag per se – Namjoon wasn’t at war, after all; he was having fun with his friends – but you still found yourself feeling lonely every night that you couldn’t hear his voice. That was exactly why you had an alarm ready for the time Namjoon was supposed to return back to the cabin with the rest of the boys.

The alarm went off three days after your last phone call just like it was supposed to. But Namjoon didn’t call.

Suddenly concerned, you debated giving him a call yourself but then decided against it – perhaps he was tired and went straight to sleep as soon as he returned. There was no point to bother him with your call. And besides, he was supposed to be the one to call you and not the other way around.

You waited. Anxiety seemed to expand in your stomach and spread throughout your body with each passing minute because you knew that no matter how forgetful and clumsy Namjoon was, he was still very punctual and he would have hated the thought of you worrying because of him. If he really was tired, he would have at least sent you a quick text to let you know that things were okay.

Something had to happen to him.

Finally, after not hearing from him for three and a half hours since the alarm you’d set rang, you picked your phone up with shaky hands and found Namjoon’s number, ready to dial it and deal with whatever happened next. If he was tired, you wouldn’t talk long. All you needed was to hear his voice.

Surprisingly, however, Namjoon picked up on the first ring. The only concerning thing was that, although he answered the call, he didn’t say anything.

“Namjoon!” you gasped breathlessly. “Hi. Can you hear me? Is everything okay?”

“Hi,” he answered slowly. He sounded different – his voice was weirdly slow and monotonous –  but perhaps that was just the exhaustion. “I need to talk to you.”

“God, did something happen?” you asked, sitting down on your bed before you continued. Your body was shaking too hard for you to keep on standing. “Are you okay? Did you get hurt? Where are y—”

“I—I’m fine,” he answered as you listened to an odd buzzing in the background of the call. “I did a lot of thinking during the trip.”

You were confused as you waited for him to carry on but, clearly, he needed reassurance that you were still listening, so you cleared your throat. “Right. That’s good.”

“I have decided something,” he said, his voice getting deeper with each word. A little surprised to hear the warped way he was talking, you pulled the phone away from your ear to check if you were truly talking to Namjoon – you were. Once you put the phone back to your ear, however, you’ve missed part of what he’d said, “—and it didn’t make sense to me. So, I think we should end this.”

“What?” you asked, unable to guess what he could have said in the few seconds that you weren’t listening to him. “End what?”

“This relationship,” he said. A bolt of shock ran through your body and you were on your feet in a second, squinting your eyes in confusion. Instead of hearing him explain why he didn’t call you, you heard him attempt to break up with you. “I don’t think it’s going anywhere.”

“You don’t—what are you talking about?” you asked. You absolutely weren’t expecting this. “Did something happen during the trip? A-are you okay?”

“No. Like I said, I just thought a lot,” he said. “It hurts me to say this but I think it’s the right thing to do. I was always honest with you and, the truth is, we don’t belong together.”

“W-we don’t belong together?” you repeated, not even trying to conceal the disbelief in your voice. “Namjoon—”

“I’m sorry,” he cut you off. “I have to say goodbye now.”

“You—Namjoon, I—” you tried but it was pointless as short beeps answered your words, indicating that he had hung up.

Blinking your eyes, you pulled your phone away, unable to tell if it was a real conversation you’ve just had or if, perhaps, you’d dreamt it all. Pinching yourself was no use – your whole body was numb.

You spent a good fifteen minutes just staring at your phone after Namjoon had ended the call. Replaying everything he’d said, you tried to make sense of his words but couldn’t, no matter how hard you tried.

How was it possible that a three-day mountain-climbing trip lead Namjoon – who swore he loved you every night before he went to sleep – to a conclusion that he no longer wanted to be with you? What kind of thoughts did he get during the trip?

And, most importantly, what was the reason why he didn’t call you sooner? Had something else happened that made him want to break up with you – what the hell could it have been?! – or was he just scared of telling you that he no longer wanted to be with you?

Lacking closure and needing a proper explanation about what was going on – you just couldn’t understand why he would break up with you so out of the blue; it was extremely unlike Namjoon to give important news over the phone, not to mention how long it took him to prepare to give this news – you dialed his phone number again, only to be cut off by the operator, informing you that the person you were trying to reach was unavailable.

“What the—he turned his phone off?” you asked out loud, the hostility in your voice throwing you off.

You didn’t think this was real. It didn’t make much sense for Namjoon to play a prank on you, but it didn’t make a lot of sense for him to abruptly break up with you, either. And you couldn’t decide if you were starting to feel angry because you couldn’t figure out what was going on or because a small—and, clearly, very insecure—part of you actually believed that there was a chance that Namjoon did decide to break up with you.

Suddenly, your phone started to ring and you nearly flinched in surprise. Unfortunately, it wasn’t Namjoon’s name that lit up your screen – it was Hoseok’s.

“Hello?” you picked up, albeit tentatively.

First, a confusing call from your boyfriend — or was it ex-boyfriend now? — and then an unexpected call from his best friend? You dreaded to think what Hoseok was going to tell you.

“Hey! Where are you? We’re back in Seoul,” he said, his voice slightly panicked.

“What? You’re here?” you asked, more confused by the second. “W-where’s—”

“Yeah, we ended up having to cut our climbing short – Yoongi got a fever but he’s okay now – so we came back home. Uh, Namjoon lost his phone at the airport, though,” Hoseok explained and you felt a cold wave wash over your body. “We’ve been looking for it for the past three hours. Listen—”

Your heart almost stopped as your previously numb body suddenly became ice cold, freezing every thought you might have had, and only allowing you to reach the obvious conclusions: it wasn’t Namjoon who’d called you. He wasn’t the one who broke up with you.

Interrupting Hoseok, you quietly spoke, “I, um—I think someone may have found his phone.”

Hoseok was surprised to hear this. “What?”

“Yeah. I got a call from, uh—from Namjoon, I had assumed,” you explained, slowly starting to realize what had to have happened: someone chose to play a cruel prank on you. “About two hours ago.”

“But that’s impossible,” Hoseok said, clearly struggling to understand what you’ve already understood. “Namjoon lost his phone—are you sure the call was from him? You talked to him?”

You couldn’t believe your naïve, ready-to-believe-anything mind. Had you really thought – even if just for a moment – that Namjoon would actually do something like this? He would never even try to. And you knew that. Or, at least, you thought you did.

“I did,” you confirmed, suddenly desperately wanting to hit something. “It even sounded like him. God, I can’t—”

“Hey, do you want to talk to him?” Hoseok cut you off, noticing how the coldness slowly started to leave your voice, only to be replaced with desperate fury. Whatever not-Namjoon had said to you on the phone was clearly no longer Hoseok’s business. “He’s here right now. He went around the terminal with Taehyung but, uh, they didn’t find anything from what I see. He’s already extending his hand for the phone, so I—”

“Hey, it’s me,” Namjoon’s voice replaced Hoseok’s before the older boy finished his sentence. You inhaled deeply, your heart immediately starting to beat faster at the sound of your boyfriend’s words – this was Namjoon. How could you ever mistake someone else for him? “I’m so sorry about this. I-I misplaced my phone and I don’t know where it is. I couldn’t call you.”

“That’s, uh…” you started to say, noticing how difficult it was to talk to him – even though you knew it was really him this time – after the fake break-up you went through not even half an hour ago. “That’s okay.”

“I figure it’s possible that my phone is just somewhere in my suitcase but—”

“Someone found it, Joon,” you cut him off, wanting to get this out faster so you could decide what to do next. “Someone found it and called me, pretending to be you.”

Namjoon went quiet on the other end and you were starting to think your phone had died, but then he finally spoke.

“W-what?” he asked, just as confused as Hoseok was before when you’d tried – and failed – to give him a quick breakthrough of what had happened. “What did they say?”

“They, um, they broke up with me,” you revealed, suddenly feeling choked. “Well, I thought it was you doing the breaking-up.”

“Jesus,” Namjoon exhaled. He was much faster at understanding who had his phone than Hoseok was. “Are you home right now?”

“Yes, I’m—”

“Okay, I’m on my way,” he said. “Block my number. If I’ll want to call you until I get to your place, I’ll have to figure out how to use a payphone. O-or I’ll just take Hoseok’s phone with me. Anyway – do not pick up any more calls from my number, do you hear me?”

“Okay,” you said weakly but then swallowed your tears and cleared your throat to try to lose the uncomfortable ball of anxiety stuck there. “W-what are you going to do about the phone?”

“I couldn’t care less about it, to be honest with you,” Namjoon said. You were starting to have a hard time understanding him as the wind started to blow all around him. He must have left the airport already. “But I do know that no one will ever get away with this. How long ago did they call you?”

“Not very long,” you said. “About twenty or so minutes.”

“My God, you spent twenty minutes thinking I wanted to break up with you,” he spoke quietly, not needing you to say it – he could hear all the emotions you’ve gone through in your voice. “Baby, I’m so sorry.”

You could feel the tears returning – you didn’t welcome them because you couldn’t understand what was the point of crying; all had ended well, right? – so you shook your head to hopefully get rid of them.

“It’s okay,” you whispered. “We’re okay. Right?”

Inhaling sharply after your question, Namjoon stopped walking to give you his full attention.

“Don’t ever ask me that again,” he warned you. “We are more than okay. We’re perfect. I love you so much and I would never even think about breaking up with you. You have no idea how angry it makes me to hear you doubt that right now.”

You didn’t want him to feel this way. You wanted to tell him that you never believed the words the person on the other end of the call had said while pretending to be him but you couldn’t. The part of you that had considered it to be possible for Namjoon to break up with you over the phone had spread your hidden insecurity about this relationship all over your mind.

“I’m sorr—” you started to say but Namjoon wasn’t having it.

“I’m on my way to see you,” he said, not wanting you to apologize because he felt like he should have been the one saying sorry to you. Guilt was trying to eat him alive as he couldn’t come up with an explanation why he didn’t immediately use someone else’s phone to let you know he’d lost his. “I’m going to hold you and kiss you to make up for this and for all the nights that I didn’t get to see you. I love you, yeah? I love you very much and nothing – or no one – is ever going to change that even if they try. Okay?”

You needed to hear this and he knew it. Namjoon never got tired of reassuring you that he loved you and that everything was going to work out when your anxiety acted up – he always knew what he had to say and he said it. And, although you felt bad that he’d dropped every other errand he might have had after the trip just to see you, you couldn’t bring yourself to tell him not to come.

You wanted to see him and you’d have been right to assume that he wanted to see you just as much.

“Okay,” you nodded even if he couldn’t see you, smiling gently as a warm tear still managed to slide down your cheek. “I love you.”

“Not really, we won’t be going up very high and I don’t think the Alps are quite as dangerous,” Namjoon said. “Although, I’ve never seen the movie, so you know – maybe this will turn out to be Everest: Bangtan Edition.”

You were the one laughing now.

“Please don’t actually attempt to climb the Everest on your next trip,” you asked half-jokingly.

“As long as you don’t mention this idea to Jungkook, I think we’re fine,” Namjoon replied, both of you smiling in your respectful bedrooms, hundreds and hundreds of kilometers between you.

“Stay safe, please,” you asked again after a moment’s silence. “And give my best wishes to the rest of the team.”

“Will do,” your boyfriend said, sighing deeply as he realized – after noticing that it was well after 1am in his timezone already – that he couldn’t prolong his conversation with you any longer. “I have to go, baby.”

“I know,” you said, trying not to sound too sad because you were really happy for him – he was going to experience something amazing with his friends – but, at the same time, you have never gone more than one day without talking to him in any way, so this was stressful. “Get some rest tonight.”

“Okay,” he replied. “I love you.”

“I love you, too.”

“I’ll call you in three days,” he promised then. “Take care of yourself for me, baby.”

The days when you didn’t talk to your boyfriend didn’t really drag per se – Namjoon wasn’t at war, after all; he was having fun with his friends – but you still found yourself feeling lonely every night that you couldn’t hear his voice. That was exactly why you had an alarm ready for the time Namjoon was supposed to return back to the cabin with the rest of the boys.

The alarm went off three days after your last phone call just like it was supposed to. But Namjoon didn’t call.

Suddenly concerned, you debated giving him a call yourself but then decided against it – perhaps he was tired and went straight to sleep as soon as he returned. There was no point to bother him with your call. And besides, he was supposed to be the one to call you and not the other way around.

You waited. Anxiety seemed to expand in your stomach and spread throughout your body with each passing minute because you knew that no matter how forgetful and clumsy Namjoon was, he was still very punctual and he would have hated the thought of you worrying because of him. If he really was tired, he would have at least sent you a quick text to let you know that things were okay.

Something had to happen to him.

Finally, after not hearing from him for three and a half hours since the alarm you’d set rang, you picked your phone up with shaky hands and found Namjoon’s number, ready to dial it and deal with whatever happened next. If he was tired, you wouldn’t talk long. All you needed was to hear his voice.

Surprisingly, however, Namjoon picked up on the first ring. The only concerning thing was that, although he answered the call, he didn’t say anything.

“Namjoon!” you gasped breathlessly. “Hi. Can you hear me? Is everything okay?”

“Hi,” he answered slowly. He sounded different – his voice was weirdly slow and monotonous –  but perhaps that was just the exhaustion. “I need to talk to you.”

“God, did something happen?” you asked, sitting down on your bed before you continued. Your body was shaking too hard for you to keep on standing. “Are you okay? Did you get hurt? Where are y—”

“I—I’m fine,” he answered as you listened to an odd buzzing in the background of the call. “I did a lot of thinking during the trip.”

You were confused as you waited for him to carry on but, clearly, he needed reassurance that you were still listening, so you cleared your throat. “Right. That’s good.”

“I have decided something,” he said, his voice getting deeper with each word. A little surprised to hear the warped way he was talking, you pulled the phone away from your ear to check if you were truly talking to Namjoon – you were. Once you put the phone back to your ear, however, you’ve missed part of what he’d said, “—and it didn’t make sense to me. So, I think we should end this.”

“What?” you asked, unable to guess what he could have said in the few seconds that you weren’t listening to him. “End what?”

“This relationship,” he said. A bolt of shock ran through your body and you were on your feet in a second, squinting your eyes in confusion. Instead of hearing him explain why he didn’t call you, you heard him attempt to break up with you. “I don’t think it’s going anywhere.”

“You don’t—what are you talking about?” you asked. You absolutely weren’t expecting this. “Did something happen during the trip? A-are you okay?”

“No. Like I said, I just thought a lot,” he said. “It hurts me to say this but I think it’s the right thing to do. I was always honest with you and, the truth is, we don’t belong together.”

“W-we don’t belong together?” you repeated, not even trying to conceal the disbelief in your voice. “Namjoon—”

“I’m sorry,” he cut you off. “I have to say goodbye now.”

“You—Namjoon, I—” you tried but it was pointless as short beeps answered your words, indicating that he had hung up.

Blinking your eyes, you pulled your phone away, unable to tell if it was a real conversation you’ve just had or if, perhaps, you’d dreamt it all. Pinching yourself was no use – your whole body was numb.

You spent a good fifteen minutes just staring at your phone after Namjoon had ended the call. Replaying everything he’d said, you tried to make sense of his words but couldn’t, no matter how hard you tried.

How was it possible that a three-day mountain-climbing trip lead Namjoon – who swore he loved you every night before he went to sleep – to a conclusion that he no longer wanted to be with you? What kind of thoughts did he get during the trip?

And, most importantly, what was the reason why he didn’t call you sooner? Had something else happened that made him want to break up with you – what the hell could it have been?! – or was he just scared of telling you that he no longer wanted to be with you?

Lacking closure and needing a proper explanation about what was going on – you just couldn’t understand why he would break up with you so out of the blue; it was extremely unlike Namjoon to give important news over the phone, not to mention how long it took him to prepare to give this news – you dialed his phone number again, only to be cut off by the operator, informing you that the person you were trying to reach was unavailable.

“What the—he turned his phone off?” you asked out loud, the hostility in your voice throwing you off.

You didn’t think this was real. It didn’t make much sense for Namjoon to play a prank on you, but it didn’t make a lot of sense for him to abruptly break up with you, either. And you couldn’t decide if you were starting to feel angry because you couldn’t figure out what was going on or because a small—and, clearly, very insecure—part of you actually believed that there was a chance that Namjoon did decide to break up with you.

Suddenly, your phone started to ring and you nearly flinched in surprise. Unfortunately, it wasn’t Namjoon’s name that lit up your screen – it was Hoseok’s.

“Hello?” you picked up, albeit tentatively.

First, a confusing call from your boyfriend — or was it ex-boyfriend now? — and then an unexpected call from his best friend? You dreaded to think what Hoseok was going to tell you.

“Hey! Where are you? We’re back in Seoul,” he said, his voice slightly panicked.

“What? You’re here?” you asked, more confused by the second. “W-where’s—”

“Yeah, we ended up having to cut our climbing short – Yoongi got a fever but he’s okay now – so we came back home. Uh, Namjoon lost his phone at the airport, though,” Hoseok explained and you felt a cold wave wash over your body. “We’ve been looking for it for the past three hours. Listen—”

Your heart almost stopped as your previously numb body suddenly became ice cold, freezing every thought you might have had, and only allowing you to reach the obvious conclusions: it wasn’t Namjoon who’d called you. He wasn’t the one who broke up with you.

Interrupting Hoseok, you quietly spoke, “I, um—I think someone may have found his phone.”

Hoseok was surprised to hear this. “What?”

“Yeah. I got a call from, uh—from Namjoon, I had assumed,” you explained, slowly starting to realize what had to have happened: someone chose to play a cruel prank on you. “About two hours ago.”

“But that’s impossible,” Hoseok said, clearly struggling to understand what you’ve already understood. “Namjoon lost his phone—are you sure the call was from him? You talked to him?”

You couldn’t believe your naïve, ready-to-believe-anything mind. Had you really thought – even if just for a moment – that Namjoon would actually do something like this? He would never even try to. And you knew that. Or, at least, you thought you did.

“I did,” you confirmed, suddenly desperately wanting to hit something. “It even sounded like him. God, I can’t—”

“Hey, do you want to talk to him?” Hoseok cut you off, noticing how the coldness slowly started to leave your voice, only to be replaced with desperate fury. Whatever not-Namjoon had said to you on the phone was clearly no longer Hoseok’s business. “He’s here right now. He went around the terminal with Taehyung but, uh, they didn’t find anything from what I see. He’s already extending his hand for the phone, so I—”

“Hey, it’s me,” Namjoon’s voice replaced Hoseok’s before the older boy finished his sentence. You inhaled deeply, your heart immediately starting to beat faster at the sound of your boyfriend’s words – this was Namjoon. How could you ever mistake someone else for him? “I’m so sorry about this. I-I misplaced my phone and I don’t know where it is. I couldn’t call you.”

“That’s, uh…” you started to say, noticing how difficult it was to talk to him – even though you knew it was really him this time – after the fake break-up you went through not even half an hour ago. “That’s okay.”

“I figure it’s possible that my phone is just somewhere in my suitcase but—”

“Someone found it, Joon,” you cut him off, wanting to get this out faster so you could decide what to do next. “Someone found it and called me, pretending to be you.”

Namjoon went quiet on the other end and you were starting to think your phone had died, but then he finally spoke.

“W-what?” he asked, just as confused as Hoseok was before when you’d tried – and failed – to give him a quick breakthrough of what had happened. “What did they say?”

“They, um, they broke up with me,” you revealed, suddenly feeling choked. “Well, I thought it was you doing the breaking-up.”

“Jesus,” Namjoon exhaled. He was much faster at understanding who had his phone than Hoseok was. “Are you home right now?”

“Yes, I’m—”

“Okay, I’m on my way,” he said. “Block my number. If I’ll want to call you until I get to your place, I’ll have to figure out how to use a payphone. O-or I’ll just take Hoseok’s phone with me. Anyway – do not pick up any more calls from my number, do you hear me?”

“Okay,” you said weakly but then swallowed your tears and cleared your throat to try to lose the uncomfortable ball of anxiety stuck there. “W-what are you going to do about the phone?”

“I couldn’t care less about it, to be honest with you,” Namjoon said. You were starting to have a hard time understanding him as the wind started to blow all around him. He must have left the airport already. “But I do know that no one will ever get away with this. How long ago did they call you?”

“Not very long,” you said. “About twenty or so minutes.”

“My God, you spent twenty minutes thinking I wanted to break up with you,” he spoke quietly, not needing you to say it – he could hear all the emotions you’ve gone through in your voice. “Baby, I’m so sorry.”

You could feel the tears returning – you didn’t welcome them because you couldn’t understand what was the point of crying; all had ended well, right? – so you shook your head to hopefully get rid of them.

“It’s okay,” you whispered. “We’re okay. Right?”

Inhaling sharply after your question, Namjoon stopped walking to give you his full attention.

“Don’t ever ask me that again,” he warned you. “We are more than okay. We’re perfect. I love you so much and I would never even think about breaking up with you. You have no idea how angry it makes me to hear you doubt that right now.”

You didn’t want him to feel this way. You wanted to tell him that you never believed the words the person on the other end of the call had said while pretending to be him but you couldn’t. The part of you that had considered it to be possible for Namjoon to break up with you over the phone had spread your hidden insecurity about this relationship all over your mind.

“I’m sorr—” you started to say but Namjoon wasn’t having it.

“I’m on my way to see you,” he said, not wanting you to apologize because he felt like he should have been the one saying sorry to you. Guilt was trying to eat him alive as he couldn’t come up with an explanation why he didn’t immediately use someone else’s phone to let you know he’d lost his. “I’m going to hold you and kiss you to make up for this and for all the nights that I didn’t get to see you. I love you, yeah? I love you very much and nothing – or no one – is ever going to change that even if they try. Okay?”

You needed to hear this and he knew it. Namjoon never got tired of reassuring you that he loved you and that everything was going to work out when your anxiety acted up – he always knew what he had to say and he said it. And, although you felt bad that he’d dropped every other errand he might have had after the trip just to see you, you couldn’t bring yourself to tell him not to come.

You wanted to see him and you’d have been right to assume that he wanted to see you just as much.

“Okay,” you nodded even if he couldn’t see you, smiling gently as a warm tear still managed to slide down your cheek. “I love you.”

“Not really, we won’t be going up very high and I don’t think the Alps are quite as dangerous,” Namjoon said. “Although, I’ve never seen the movie, so you know – maybe this will turn out to be Everest: Bangtan Edition.”

You were the one laughing now.

“Please don’t actually attempt to climb the Everest on your next trip,” you asked half-jokingly.

“As long as you don’t mention this idea to Jungkook, I think we’re fine,” Namjoon replied, both of you smiling in your respectful bedrooms, hundreds and hundreds of kilometers between you.

“Stay safe, please,” you asked again after a moment’s silence. “And give my best wishes to the rest of the team.”

“Will do,” your boyfriend said, sighing deeply as he realized – after noticing that it was well after 1am in his timezone already – that he couldn’t prolong his conversation with you any longer. “I have to go, baby.”

“I know,” you said, trying not to sound too sad because you were really happy for him – he was going to experience something amazing with his friends – but, at the same time, you have never gone more than one day without talking to him in any way, so this was stressful. “Get some rest tonight.”

“Okay,” he replied. “I love you.”

“I love you, too.”

“I’ll call you in three days,” he promised then. “Take care of yourself for me, baby.”

The days when you didn’t talk to your boyfriend didn’t really drag per se – Namjoon wasn’t at war, after all; he was having fun with his friends – but you still found yourself feeling lonely every night that you couldn’t hear his voice. That was exactly why you had an alarm ready for the time Namjoon was supposed to return back to the cabin with the rest of the boys.

The alarm went off three days after your last phone call just like it was supposed to. But Namjoon didn’t call.

Suddenly concerned, you debated giving him a call yourself but then decided against it – perhaps he was tired and went straight to sleep as soon as he returned. There was no point to bother him with your call. And besides, he was supposed to be the one to call you and not the other way around.

You waited. Anxiety seemed to expand in your stomach and spread throughout your body with each passing minute because you knew that no matter how forgetful and clumsy Namjoon was, he was still very punctual and he would have hated the thought of you worrying because of him. If he really was tired, he would have at least sent you a quick text to let you know that things were okay.

Something had to happen to him.

Finally, after not hearing from him for three and a half hours since the alarm you’d set rang, you picked your phone up with shaky hands and found Namjoon’s number, ready to dial it and deal with whatever happened next. If he was tired, you wouldn’t talk long. All you needed was to hear his voice.

Surprisingly, however, Namjoon picked up on the first ring. The only concerning thing was that, although he answered the call, he didn’t say anything.

“Namjoon!” you gasped breathlessly. “Hi. Can you hear me? Is everything okay?”

“Hi,” he answered slowly. He sounded different – his voice was weirdly slow and monotonous –  but perhaps that was just the exhaustion. “I need to talk to you.”

“God, did something happen?” you asked, sitting down on your bed before you continued. Your body was shaking too hard for you to keep on standing. “Are you okay? Did you get hurt? Where are y—”

“I—I’m fine,” he answered as you listened to an odd buzzing in the background of the call. “I did a lot of thinking during the trip.”

You were confused as you waited for him to carry on but, clearly, he needed reassurance that you were still listening, so you cleared your throat. “Right. That’s good.”

“I have decided something,” he said, his voice getting deeper with each word. A little surprised to hear the warped way he was talking, you pulled the phone away from your ear to check if you were truly talking to Namjoon – you were. Once you put the phone back to your ear, however, you’ve missed part of what he’d said, “—and it didn’t make sense to me. So, I think we should end this.”

“What?” you asked, unable to guess what he could have said in the few seconds that you weren’t listening to him. “End what?”

“This relationship,” he said. A bolt of shock ran through your body and you were on your feet in a second, squinting your eyes in confusion. Instead of hearing him explain why he didn’t call you, you heard him attempt to break up with you. “I don’t think it’s going anywhere.”

“You don’t—what are you talking about?” you asked. You absolutely weren’t expecting this. “Did something happen during the trip? A-are you okay?”

“No. Like I said, I just thought a lot,” he said. “It hurts me to say this but I think it’s the right thing to do. I was always honest with you and, the truth is, we don’t belong together.”

“W-we don’t belong together?” you repeated, not even trying to conceal the disbelief in your voice. “Namjoon—”

“I’m sorry,” he cut you off. “I have to say goodbye now.”

“You—Namjoon, I—” you tried but it was pointless as short beeps answered your words, indicating that he had hung up.

Blinking your eyes, you pulled your phone away, unable to tell if it was a real conversation you’ve just had or if, perhaps, you’d dreamt it all. Pinching yourself was no use – your whole body was numb.

You spent a good fifteen minutes just staring at your phone after Namjoon had ended the call. Replaying everything he’d said, you tried to make sense of his words but couldn’t, no matter how hard you tried.

How was it possible that a three-day mountain-climbing trip lead Namjoon – who swore he loved you every night before he went to sleep – to a conclusion that he no longer wanted to be with you? What kind of thoughts did he get during the trip?

And, most importantly, what was the reason why he didn’t call you sooner? Had something else happened that made him want to break up with you – what the hell could it have been?! – or was he just scared of telling you that he no longer wanted to be with you?

Lacking closure and needing a proper explanation about what was going on – you just couldn’t understand why he would break up with you so out of the blue; it was extremely unlike Namjoon to give important news over the phone, not to mention how long it took him to prepare to give this news – you dialed his phone number again, only to be cut off by the operator, informing you that the person you were trying to reach was unavailable.

“What the—he turned his phone off?” you asked out loud, the hostility in your voice throwing you off.

You didn’t think this was real. It didn’t make much sense for Namjoon to play a prank on you, but it didn’t make a lot of sense for him to abruptly break up with you, either. And you couldn’t decide if you were starting to feel angry because you couldn’t figure out what was going on or because a small—and, clearly, very insecure—part of you actually believed that there was a chance that Namjoon did decide to break up with you.

Suddenly, your phone started to ring and you nearly flinched in surprise. Unfortunately, it wasn’t Namjoon’s name that lit up your screen – it was Hoseok’s.

“Hello?” you picked up, albeit tentatively.

First, a confusing call from your boyfriend — or was it ex-boyfriend now? — and then an unexpected call from his best friend? You dreaded to think what Hoseok was going to tell you.

“Hey! Where are you? We’re back in Seoul,” he said, his voice slightly panicked.

“What? You’re here?” you asked, more confused by the second. “W-where’s—”

“Yeah, we ended up having to cut our climbing short – Yoongi got a fever but he’s okay now – so we came back home. Uh, Namjoon lost his phone at the airport, though,” Hoseok explained and you felt a cold wave wash over your body. “We’ve been looking for it for the past three hours. Listen—”

Your heart almost stopped as your previously numb body suddenly became ice cold, freezing every thought you might have had, and only allowing you to reach the obvious conclusions: it wasn’t Namjoon who’d called you. He wasn’t the one who broke up with you.

Interrupting Hoseok, you quietly spoke, “I, um—I think someone may have found his phone.”

Hoseok was surprised to hear this. “What?”

“Yeah. I got a call from, uh—from Namjoon, I had assumed,” you explained, slowly starting to realize what had to have happened: someone chose to play a cruel prank on you. “About two hours ago.”

“But that’s impossible,” Hoseok said, clearly struggling to understand what you’ve already understood. “Namjoon lost his phone—are you sure the call was from him? You talked to him?”

You couldn’t believe your naïve, ready-to-believe-anything mind. Had you really thought – even if just for a moment – that Namjoon would actually do something like this? He would never even try to. And you knew that. Or, at least, you thought you did.

“I did,” you confirmed, suddenly desperately wanting to hit something. “It even sounded like him. God, I can’t—”

“Hey, do you want to talk to him?” Hoseok cut you off, noticing how the coldness slowly started to leave your voice, only to be replaced with desperate fury. Whatever not-Namjoon had said to you on the phone was clearly no longer Hoseok’s business. “He’s here right now. He went around the terminal with Taehyung but, uh, they didn’t find anything from what I see. He’s already extending his hand for the phone, so I—”

“Hey, it’s me,” Namjoon’s voice replaced Hoseok’s before the older boy finished his sentence. You inhaled deeply, your heart immediately starting to beat faster at the sound of your boyfriend’s words – this was Namjoon. How could you ever mistake someone else for him? “I’m so sorry about this. I-I misplaced my phone and I don’t know where it is. I couldn’t call you.”

“That’s, uh…” you started to say, noticing how difficult it was to talk to him – even though you knew it was really him this time – after the fake break-up you went through not even half an hour ago. “That’s okay.”

“I figure it’s possible that my phone is just somewhere in my suitcase but—”

“Someone found it, Joon,” you cut him off, wanting to get this out faster so you could decide what to do next. “Someone found it and called me, pretending to be you.”

Namjoon went quiet on the other end and you were starting to think your phone had died, but then he finally spoke.

“W-what?” he asked, just as confused as Hoseok was before when you’d tried – and failed – to give him a quick breakthrough of what had happened. “What did they say?”

“They, um, they broke up with me,” you revealed, suddenly feeling choked. “Well, I thought it was you doing the breaking-up.”

“Jesus,” Namjoon exhaled. He was much faster at understanding who had his phone than Hoseok was. “Are you home right now?”

“Yes, I’m—”

“Okay, I’m on my way,” he said. “Block my number. If I’ll want to call you until I get to your place, I’ll have to figure out how to use a payphone. O-or I’ll just take Hoseok’s phone with me. Anyway – do not pick up any more calls from my number, do you hear me?”

“Okay,” you said weakly but then swallowed your tears and cleared your throat to try to lose the uncomfortable ball of anxiety stuck there. “W-what are you going to do about the phone?”

“I couldn’t care less about it, to be honest with you,” Namjoon said. You were starting to have a hard time understanding him as the wind started to blow all around him. He must have left the airport already. “But I do know that no one will ever get away with this. How long ago did they call you?”

“Not very long,” you said. “About twenty or so minutes.”

“My God, you spent twenty minutes thinking I wanted to break up with you,” he spoke quietly, not needing you to say it – he could hear all the emotions you’ve gone through in your voice. “Baby, I’m so sorry.”

You could feel the tears returning – you didn’t welcome them because you couldn’t understand what was the point of crying; all had ended well, right? – so you shook your head to hopefully get rid of them.

“It’s okay,” you whispered. “We’re okay. Right?”

Inhaling sharply after your question, Namjoon stopped walking to give you his full attention.

“Don’t ever ask me that again,” he warned you. “We are more than okay. We’re perfect. I love you so much and I would never even think about breaking up with you. You have no idea how angry it makes me to hear you doubt that right now.”

You didn’t want him to feel this way. You wanted to tell him that you never believed the words the person on the other end of the call had said while pretending to be him but you couldn’t. The part of you that had considered it to be possible for Namjoon to break up with you over the phone had spread your hidden insecurity about this relationship all over your mind.

“I’m sorr—” you started to say but Namjoon wasn’t having it.

“I’m on my way to see you,” he said, not wanting you to apologize because he felt like he should have been the one saying sorry to you. Guilt was trying to eat him alive as he couldn’t come up with an explanation why he didn’t immediately use someone else’s phone to let you know he’d lost his. “I’m going to hold you and kiss you to make up for this and for all the nights that I didn’t get to see you. I love you, yeah? I love you very much and nothing – or no one – is ever going to change that even if they try. Okay?”

You needed to hear this and he knew it. Namjoon never got tired of reassuring you that he loved you and that everything was going to work out when your anxiety acted up – he always knew what he had to say and he said it. And, although you felt bad that he’d dropped every other errand he might have had after the trip just to see you, you couldn’t bring yourself to tell him not to come.

You wanted to see him and you’d have been right to assume that he wanted to see you just as much.

“Okay,” you nodded even if he couldn’t see you, smiling gently as a warm tear still managed to slide down your cheek. “I love you.”
trail.content_abstract:
Your first encounter with sasaengs could have ruined your relationship if Namjoon and his friends hadn’t reacted fast enough.

pairing: Namjoon x Reader (feat. Hoseok)

warnings: angst

words: 2.6k

ANON REQUEST: Namjoon wanting to break up with you over the phone and you realize it’s not him.
